constraint.human: Last modified date must be greater than or equal to created date.

element.definition: A task to be performed.
The business identifier for this task.
Identifies a plan, proposal or order that this task has been created in fulfillment of.
An identifier that links together multiple tasks and other requests that were created in the same context.
element.requirements: Billing and/or reporting can be linked to whether multiple requests were created as a single unit.

element.comments: This should usually be 0..1.
element.definition: Task that this particular task is part of.
element.requirements: Allows tasks to be broken down into sub-steps (and this division can occur independent of the original task).

binding.description: The current status of the task.

element.definition: The current status of the task.
element.requirements: These states enable coordination of task status with off-the-shelf workflow solutions that support automation of tasks.

element.comments: This applies to the current status.  Look at the history of the task to see reasons for past statuses.
element.definition: An explanation as to why this task is held, failed, was refused, etc.

binding.description: The domain-specific business-contextual sub-state of the task.  For example: "Blood drawn", "IV inserted", "Awaiting physician signature", etc.

element.definition: Contains business-specific nuances of the business state.
element.requirements: There's often a need to track substates of a task - this is often variable by specific workflow implementation.

binding.description: Distinguishes whether the task is a proposal, plan or full order

element.comments: This element is immutable.  Proposed tasks, planned tasks, etc. must be distinct instances.
element.definition: Indicates the "level" of actionability associated with the Task.  I.e. Is this a proposed task, a planned task, an actionable task, etc.
A name or code (or both) briefly describing what the task involves.
The priority of the task among other tasks of the same type.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If missing, this task should be performed with normal priority
element.requirements: Used to identify the service level expected while performing a task.

element.definition: A free-text description of what is to be performed.

element.comments: If multiple resources need to be manipulated, use sub-tasks.  (This ensures that status can be tracked independently for each referenced resource.).
element.definition: The request being actioned or the resource being manipulated by this task.
element.requirements: Used to identify the thing to be done.

element.definition: The entity who benefits from the performance of the service specified in the task (e.g., the patient).
element.requirements: Used to track tasks outstanding for a beneficiary.  Do not use to track the task owner or creator (see owner and creator respectively).  This can also affect access control.

element.definition: The healthcare event  (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this task was created.
element.requirements: For some tasks it may be important to know the link between the task or episode of care the task originated within.
element.short: Healthcare event during which this task originated

element.definition: The date and time this task was created.
element.requirements: Most often used along with lastUpdated to track duration of task to supporting monitoring and management.

element.definition: The date and time of last modification to this task.
element.requirements: Used along with history to track task activity and time in a particular task state.  This enables monitoring and management.

element.definition: The creator of the task.
element.requirements: Identifies who created this task.  May be used by access control mechanisms (e.g., to ensure that only the creator can cancel a task).

element.comments: Tasks may be created with an owner not yet identified.
element.definition: The owner of this task.  The participant who can execute this task.
element.requirements: Identifies who is expected to perform this task.

binding.description: The type(s) of task performers allowed

element.definition: The type of participant that can execute the task.
element.requirements: Use to distinguish tasks on different activity queues.
element.short: requester | dispatcher | scheduler | performer | monitor | manager | acquirer | reviewer

binding.description: Indicates why the task is needed.  E.g. Suspended because patient admitted to hospital.

element.comments: This should only be included if there is no focus or if it differs from the reason indicated on the focus.
element.definition: A description or code indicating why this task needs to be performed.
Free-text information captured about the task as it progresses.
Identifies any limitations on what part of a referenced task subject request should be actioned.

mapping.map: Instead of pointing to request, would point to component of request, having these characteristics

element.requirements: Sometimes when fulfillment is sought, you don't want full fulfillment.

element.definition: Indicates the number of times the requested action should occur.
element.requirements: E.g. order that requests monthly lab tests, fulfillment is sought for 1.

element.definition: Over what time-period is fulfillment sought.
element.requirements: E.g. order that authorizes 1 year's services.  Fulfillment is sought for next 3 months.
element.short: Over what time-period is fulfillment sought

element.definition: For requests that are targeted to more than on potential recipient/target, for whom is fulfillment sought?
A reference to a formal or informal definition of the task.  For example, a protocol, a step within a defined workflow definition, etc.
element.requirements: Enables a formal definition of how he task is to be performed (e.g. using BPMN, BPEL, XPDL or other formal notation) to be associated with a task, enabling automation.

element.definition: Additional information that may be needed in the execution of the task.
element.requirements: Resources and data used to perform the task.  This data is used in the business logic of task execution, and is stored separately because it varies between workflows.

binding.description: Codes to identify types of input parameters.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.  E.g. "Comparison source", "Applicable consent", "Concommitent Medications", etc.

element.comments: If referencing a BPMN workflow or Protocol, the "system" is the URL for the workflow definition and the code is the "name" of the required input.
element.definition: A code or description indicating how the input is intended to be used as part of the task execution.
element.requirements: Inputs are named to enable task automation to bind data and pass it from one task to the next.

element.definition: The value of the input parameter as a basic type.
Outputs produced by the Task.
element.requirements: Resources and data produced during the execution the task.  This data is generated by the business logic of task execution, and is stored separately because it varies between workflows.

binding.description: Codes to identify types of input parameters.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.  E.g. "Identified issues", "Preliminary results", "Filler order", "Final results", etc.

element.definition: The name of the Output parameter.
element.requirements: Outputs are named to enable task automation to bind data and pass it from one task to the next.

element.definition: The value of the Output parameter as a basic type.
element.requirements: Task outputs can take any form.

name: Task
publisher: Health Level Seven International (Orders and Observations)

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain any narrative
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource
Last modified date must be greater than or equal to created date.

element.definition: A task to be performed.

element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created

element.comments: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.

element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded in formation is added later.
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation

element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.

element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Task IDomainResourceA task to be performed
Last modified date must be greater than or equal to created date.
identifier 0..1IdentifierTask Instance Identifier
basedOn 0..*Reference(Any)Request fulfilled by this task
requisition 0..1IdentifierRequisition or grouper id
parent 0..*Reference(Task)Composite task
status 1..1codedraft | requested | received | accepted | +
TaskStatus (Required)
statusReason 0..1CodeableConceptReason for current status
businessStatus 0..1CodeableConceptE.g. "Specimen collected", "IV prepped"
stage 1..1CodeableConceptproposed | planned | actionable +
Task Stage Codes (Extensible)
code 0..1CodeableConceptTask Type
priority 0..1codelow | normal | high
TaskPriority (Required)
description 0..1stringHuman-readable explanation of task
focus 0..1Reference(Any)What task is acting on
for 0..1Reference(Any)Beneficiary of the Task
context 0..1Reference(Encounter | EpisodeOfCare)Healthcare event during which this task originated
created I1..1dateTimeTask Creation Date
lastModified I1..1dateTimeTask Last Modified Date
requester 1..1Reference(Device | Organization | Patient | Practitioner | RelatedPerson)Task Creator
owner 0..1Reference(Device | Organization | Patient | Practitioner | RelatedPerson)Task Owner
performerType 0..*CodeableConceptrequester | dispatcher | scheduler | performer | monitor | manager | acquirer | reviewer
TaskPerformerType (Preferred)
reason 0..1CodeableConceptWhy task is needed
note 0..*AnnotationComments made about the task
fulfillment 0..1BackboneElementConstraints on fulfillment tasks
repetitions 0..1positiveIntHow many times to repeat
period 0..1PeriodOver what time-period is fulfillment sought
recipients 0..*Reference(Patient | Practitioner | RelatedPerson | Group | Organization)For whom is fulfillment sought?
definition 0..1uriTask Definition
input 0..*BackboneElementSupporting information
type 1..1CodeableConceptLabel for the input
value[x] 1..1*Input Value
output 0..*BackboneElementTask Output
type 1..1CodeableConceptOutput Name
value[x] 1..1*Output Value
